newsitem.title: CHINA: China's Xinjiang starts $361 mln fertilizer plant.
newsitem.headline: China's Xinjiang starts $361 mln fertilizer plant.

text.p: China has started work on a 3.0 billion yuan ($361 million) chemical fertilizer plant in the northwestern region of Xinjiang, officials said on Tuesday.

The new plant, listed as a key national project, would have a production capacity of 300,000 tonnes of ammonia and 520,000 tons of carbamide a year, an official with the Xinjiang Army Production Corps said by telephone.
The total investment in the project, which began construction last week, would be 3.0 billion yuan, of which $130 million would be in the form of foreign loans, the official said.
Sourcing for the loans had not yet been decided, he said.

A company under the production corps would hold an 80 percent stake in the project while firms under the Ministry of Chemical Industry and the Ministry of Geology and Mineral Resources would hold 10 percent each, he said.
Most of the factory's production would go to the production corps' farms in Xinjiang, he said.
Construction of the plant would stop during the harsh Xinjiang winter, resuming in early 1997, he said, adding the plant would be completed in 1999.
